question: In the given code, what is the main difference between lines (1) and (2)?
context:
print("Please enter your first name: ")
firstName = input()
length = len(firstName)
print(firstName)
print("My first name is: ", firstName)  # (1)
print("My first name is: " + firstName) # (2)
print("My first name has", length, "characters.")
options: A. (1) prints with automatic spacing between arguments; (2) concatenates strings.
B. (1) causes a TypeError; (2) runs correctly.
C. (1) and (2) are identical in both behavior and implementation.
D. (1) requires str() around firstName; (2) does not.

question: Given the code, what is printed for the name and year lines?
context:
fullName = "Ngoc LE"
dob = "27/02/2023"
nameList = fullName.split()
dobList  = dob.split("/")
print("Words in my full name: ", nameList)
print("elements in my date of birth: ", dobList)
print("My first name is:", nameList[0])
print("My year of birth is:", dobList[2])
options: A. My first name is: Ngoc; My year of birth is: 2023
B. My first name is: LE; My year of birth is: 27
C. My first name is: Ngoc LE; My year of birth is: 02
D. My first name is: Ngoc; My year of birth is: 02

question: For input full name 'Ngoc LE' and DOB '27/02/2023', which output format is correct?
options: A. My full name is: Ngoc LE; My date of birth is: 27-02-2023; My last name is: LE; My month of birth is: 02
B. My full name is: LE Ngoc; My date of birth is: 27/02/2023; My last name is: Ngoc; My month of birth is: 27
C. My full name is: Ngoc LE; My date of birth is: 27/02/2023; My last name is: LE; My month of birth is: 27
D. My full name is: LE Ngoc; My date of birth is: 27-02-2023; My last name is: LE; My month of birth is: 2023
